stream_context.summary: Kaze focuses on integrating Biobak’s re-worked Course 10 assets, debugging texture and actor issues, and polishing engine optimizations while live-testing on real N64 hardware and emulator.

development_findings.summary: Kaze has reduced the custom engine’s outstanding bugs to near zero and eliminated all compiler warnings, declaring he is “slowly approaching zero engine bugs.”
development_findings.quote: I fixed a bunch of annoying bugs; I am slowly approaching zero engine bugs. I actually got my entire compiler down to zero warnings.

development_findings.summary: To improve instruction-cache locality on the N64, Kaze renamed and reordered all in-level actors so identical behavior code sits contiguously in memory, rejecting an Entity-Component-System approach as inefficient.
development_findings.quote: I made it so that all actors of the same code have similar names and that makes it so we get better cache proximity… entity component system is complete garbage.

development_findings.summary: Biobak’s new Course 10 import triggered a ‘texture has too many colors’ error (Material 242); the fix involved identifying duplicate texture names and re-exporting F3D assets.
Grass overhang models clipped on real hardware; Kaze extended the overhang geometry so the seam disappears, an N64-specific visual workaround.
development_findings.quote: I had to make one change… with the grass overhangs they have some z-clipping, so I made them actually hang over here so that this just kind of disappears.

development_findings.summary: Vertex-color baking is the primary lighting technique; Kaze avoids environment color because of a Fast64 bug and relies on primitive color for gradient shading.
development_findings.quote: There is a reason environment color is disabled… we always use primitive color when we can.

development_findings.summary: A new high-poly Yoshi model required armature reconnection; missing tongue bones and an animation pointer caused mouth-opening glitches and loss of interaction until flags and sub-actions were corrected.
Tempo bush objects now randomize primitive color values for subtle brightness variance; outlines were deliberately kept per Biobak’s preference.
The donut boss asset had two textures in the same render cycle, producing an ‘illegal operation’; Kaze split the textures and scaled the new model down ~28 %.
Collapsing floor tiles now slide sideways; Kaze must mirror the model and export two collision maps because scale-by-minus-one isn’t supported.
Switching to automatic patching with f3dx3 removes the need for manual display-list edits during asset imports.

context_findings.summary: Kaze streams from a basement space ‘banished’ by Zeina, noting the cooler temperature and casually referencing their personal dynamic.
context_findings.quote: Zeina’s banished me here, so where I am there isn’t much heat because I am in the basement.

context_findings.summary: He takes pride in visual quality, claiming the project is the best-looking game on N64 hardware.
context_findings.quote: I don’t think you can even make the case that there’s a better-looking N64 game than this anywhere in the world.

context_findings.summary: Kaze’s design philosophy prizes low-level control; he calls anything between assembly and very high-level code ‘mental illness.’
context_findings.quote: There’s only two programming languages, assembly and high level. Anything after that is mental illness.

context_findings.summary: He trusts his own memory and git; states he has never broken something without being able to trace it.
context_findings.quote: For source control I have git and I have never in my life broken something without being able to figure out what I broke.

biobak.summary: Delivered a full Course 10 asset overhaul—including bushes, donut boss, collapsing floors, and refined Yoshi model—prompting in-stream feedback loops on color, outlines, and collision.
Requested greener plane textures and brightness variance on foliage; Kaze implemented randomized primitive color to satisfy visual direction.

zeina.summary: Mentioned only tangentially as Kaze’s wife who assigned him to work in the basement; no project contributions noted in this stream.

key_stories.title: Instruction-Cache Breakthrough
key_stories.summary: Kaze realized Mario’s behavior loop never evicts from cache, prompting a systematic renaming of actors so identical behaviors sit contiguously in memory.
key_stories.challenge: Performance drops due to instruction-cache misses on real hardware.
key_stories.process: Benchmarked cache misses, verified cyclical count of ‘2’, then reordered actor names for memory adjacency.
key_stories.outcome: Behavior code stays resident in cache, boosting frame-rate; Kaze publicly dismisses ECS in favor of this approach.
key_stories.key_quote: My game is already so optimized that Mario’s behavior loop never gets thrown out of cache, which is crazy.

key_stories.title: The Broken Yoshi
key_stories.summary: Importing Biobak’s new Yoshi model caused missing animations, double dialogue, and fruit-eating failures.
key_stories.challenge: New armature lacked tongue bones and animation pointers, and behavior flags fired twice.
key_stories.process: Re-hooked bones in Blender, restored vertex weights, removed redundant ‘object cutscene done’ logic, and adjusted sub-action timing.
key_stories.outcome: Yoshi now animates, follows Mario’s eyes, and is usable for level testing, though minor dialogue duplication remains for later.
key_stories.key_quote: We fixed him enough to where we can go into him. That’s all we needed.

key_stories.title: Grass Overhang Clipping
key_stories.summary: Beautiful new grass cliffs suffered Z-fighting on real N64 hardware.
key_stories.challenge: Hardware depth precision caused visible seams on overhang geometry.
key_stories.process: Extended the overhang mesh so the problematic seam falls outside the visible area.
key_stories.outcome: Visual flaw removed; asset now looks identical on hardware and emulator.
key_stories.key_quote: I made them actually hang over so that this just kind of disappears.

open_questions.context: Kaze casually announced a sponsored F3 competition with cash prizes for the most-voted ROM hack.
questions: How large is the cash reward and how will voting work?
Why introduce monetary incentives now, and how does it fit Return to Yoshi’s Island’s release timeline?

open_questions.context: Kaze dismisses ECS and relies on renaming actors for cache locality.
questions: Can Kaze elaborate on the profiling data that led to this decision?
How does this approach scale as levels grow?
What lessons could modern developers draw from N64 cache constraints?

open_questions.context: Kaze noted the switch from manual to automatic display-list patching.
questions: What problems did manual patching cause previously?
How reliable is the new pipeline across contributors?
Could Biobak or others describe how this changes their workflow?

open_questions.context: Kaze bakes lighting into vertex colors, sacrificing shade color modulation.
questions: What specific visual trade-offs were accepted?
Are there scenarios where dynamic lighting is still used?
How does this technique compare to other late-era N64 titles?

open_questions.context: The collapsing tiles now slide sideways, requiring mirrored models and extra collision exports.
questions: Why the pivot from vertical collapse to horizontal slide?
How will this mechanic be communicated to players?
Could Zeina or Biobak discuss the visual storytelling of the scratch marks?

open_questions.context: Kaze tries to ensure the game remains 32-bit only, wary of GCC emitting 64-bit instructions.
questions: What tools or flags are being used to enforce 32-bit code?
Has any real hardware bug surfaced due to accidental 64-bit opcodes?
Could Sauraen or other toolmakers shed light on compiler constraints?
